mRNA vaccines, such as those developed for COVID-19, do not enter the cell nucleus where DNA is located and therefore cannot interact with or alter human DNA. Instead, the mRNA provides instructions to cells to produce a harmless spike protein, triggering an immune response. The mRNA is quickly broken down by the body after its job is done.

Studies and real-world data have shown that vaccinated individuals do not experience decreased fertility compared to unvaccinated individuals. Major health organizations, including the CDC and American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, support vaccination for people planning pregnancy, currently pregnant, or breastfeeding.

Vaccine ingredients are publicly available and strictly regulated; they include lipids, salts, and stabilizers, but no microelectronics of any kind.
